results.content:
I have finished about 1/3 of this course and while it is useful for my purposes I don't think I would recommend it to anyone. It claims to be complete yet I see no coverage responsive design (i.e. layout for mobile first) which is one of the big selling points for Bootstrap 3.

Having completed another Bootstrap course on a different platform I find this one useful for filling in a few details that weren't covered. However most of this I could get by just reading the API myself.

results.content: Overall this is a great course. I'd like to suggest one improvement that at the beginning of every project, there should be a sample of the end-product (probably a picture). That would help students to have an idea of what they'd learn to develop as well as proactively knowing what a specific code means or attempting to do it themselves before watching the tutorials. I think that little change will greatly improve our experience. Other than that, this course is really helpful. Thanks a lot!

results.content:
You may learn something if you're an experienced coder, but there are way too many issues with this course to recommend it, whether free or at any price. 

The first major hurdle is the presenter's limited English language skills. He's difficult to understand most of the time, and sometimes what he says makes no sense.

If you can get past that, the next major issue is that the presenter seems to be "winging it" through the entire course, and there is no apparent effort made to edit any of the videos, despite the very frequent mistakes. So you get to experience hours of the presenter typing the same code over and over, making the same coding mistakes and typos over and over, and then trying to figure out what he did wrong and how to fix each problem. I'm fine with trial and error when I'm coding my own project from scratch, but for a paid course the excess typing and unedited mistakes were a big waste of my time.

The teaching ideology of this course seems to be that if you type it over and over, you will learn it. This is helpful for the first half of the course where Shahzaib shows you how to use a lot of useful Bootstrap components, but there is very little time spent actually teaching the fundamental what's, how's and why's of Bootstrap. I guess his assumption is that you don't need to really know anything about Bootstrap as long as you know the basic classes and where to use them in your code. This is my second Bootstrap course, and after completing 100% of the course, I definitely still do not feel like a "Bootstrap Master". 

Lastly, the quality of the web pages being created in these projects would not acceptable for professional web designers. The designs are lazy, sloppy and error-ridden. Pages have horizontal scrollbars, they do not all work properly on different size screens (not responsive), there are spacing/padding issues, etc. I discovered late in the course that Shahzaib was actually copying designs that are available as free theme downloads from startbootstrap.com. That might have been fine on it's own, but what you end up with after completing the projects are poorly coded, barely working imitations. I would have been better off just downloading those high quality, professionally made, free themes from the startbootstrap.com website, and trying to learn on my own by going through the HTML code.

The course wasn't a complete waste of time, but it was a very frustrating how little value it really offered, and how little I got out of it for how much time I invested (about 3 weeks working through it part time). Shahzaib knows Bootstrap and has the potential to offer a good course, but I can't recommend this course until he's fixed these issues and actually invested the time into making a quality and worthwhile course. 
Unfortunately I don't have a better alternative to this course to suggest, other than googling freely available articles and training videos from genuine Bootstrap experts.
results.content_html:

The first major hurdle is the presenter's limited English language skills. He's difficult to understand most of the time, and sometimes what he says makes no sense.

If you can get past that, the next major issue is that the presenter seems to be "winging it" through the entire course, and there is no apparent effort made to edit any of the videos, despite the very frequent mistakes. So you get to experience hours of the presenter typing the same code over and over, making the same coding mistakes and typos over and over, and then trying to figure out what he did wrong and how to fix each problem. I'm fine with trial and error when I'm coding my own project from scratch, but for a paid course the excess typing and unedited mistakes were a big waste of my time.

The teaching ideology of this course seems to be that if you type it over and over, you will learn it. Lastly, the quality of the web pages being created in these projects would not acceptable for professional web designers. The designs are lazy, sloppy and error-ridden. Pages have horizontal scrollbars, they do not all work properly on different size screens (not responsive), there are spacing/padding issues, etc. I discovered late in the course that Shahzaib was actually copying designs that are available as free theme downloads from startbootstrap.com. That might have been fine on it's own, but what you end up with after completing the projects are poorly coded, barely working imitations. results.content: When I started I had very little knowledge of how Bootstrap worked, and at the end of this course I can say that it really helps. I'm giving it 4 stars because I think most people want to learn bootstrap to make their websites both usable on desktops and mobile devices, but the projects you make in this course mostly only work on desktops, because if you make your browser the size of a smartphone, you'll see that things stack on top of each other, which is not the way it should be. Shahzaib Zamal (the instructor) is very understandable even though he has an accent, so don't worry about it.
results.content_html: When I started I had very little knowledge of how Bootstrap worked, and at the end of this course I can say that it really helps. I'm giving it 4 stars because I think most people want to learn bootstrap to make their websites both usable on desktops and mobile devices, but the projects you make in this course mostly only work on desktops, because if you make your browser the size of a smartphone, you'll see that things stack on top of each other, which is not the way it should be. Shahzaib Zamal (the instructor) is very understandable even though he has an accent, so don't worry about it.

results.content:
The course is broken into two main components: - Bootstrap Tools and Elements - A series of 4 projects. Bootstrap Tools and Elements The course runs through the main points of Bootstrap and covers it well enough. One caveat - coverage of the Bootstrap Grid system is minimal and this is a pity because this is the backbone of Bootstrap. 4 Projects This section is poor quality and the projects are very basic. Examples: Photo Gallery Project Section 3 > Lecture 45 Carousel of images with a grey bar on the right hand side is not "perfect" as the teacher suggests. In general, the teacher fixes errors & changes direction as he codes with little explanation. He seems to be coding "on the fly". It would have been better if he built the pages OFF camera first and then repeated the build ON camera after he finalized how best to do it. E-commerce project Section 5 > Lecture 52 This is very, very confusing with a lot of chopping and changing. Also, some coding practices are questionable in the projects section: Examples: - The use of the break tag
to add space under an element. This should be done by adding a style. - The use of inline styles This should be done by adding a style. Overall, while the projects are poor, the course is OK to become familiar with Bootstrap elements and that is why I give it 2 stars. Even though other students have asked about this, the course still provides NO resources or completed code to download. I think calling it "The Complete Bootstrap Masterclass Course" is not really accurate. I got the course on sale so will not be looking for a refund.
results.content_html:
The course is broken into two main components:
- Bootstrap Tools and Elements
- A series of 4 projects.

Bootstrap Tools and Elements
The course runs through the main points of Bootstrap and covers it well enough.
One caveat - coverage of the Bootstrap Grid system is minimal and this is a pity because this is the backbone of Bootstrap.

4 Projects
This section is poor quality and the projects are very basic.

Examples:

Photo Gallery Project
Section 3 > Lecture 45
Carousel of images with a grey bar on the right hand side is not "perfect" as the teacher suggests.

In general, the teacher fixes errors & changes direction as he codes with little explanation.
He seems to be coding "on the fly".
It would have been better if he built the pages OFF camera first and then repeated the build ON camera after he finalized how best to do it.

E-commerce project
Section 5 > Lecture 52
This is very, very confusing with a lot of chopping and changing.

Also, some coding practices are questionable in the projects section:
Examples:
- The use of the break tag
to add space under an element.
This should be done by adding a style.

- The use of inline styles
This should be done by adding a style.

Overall, while the projects are poor, the course is OK to become familiar with Bootstrap elements and that is why I give it 2 stars.

Even though other students have asked about this, the course still provides NO resources or completed code to download.

I think calling it "The Complete Bootstrap Masterclass Course" is not really accurate.

I got the course on sale so will not be looking for a refund.

results.content:
I understand the accent and the difficulty in teaching in a second language, but Shahzaib really should slow down with the speech patterns.  He does a good job with the language but goes very fast when talking.  Also get away from using the term perfect so often, very few things in life are perfect.
I would also recommend that you follow "Best Practices" when writing code.  It is obvious you have a good deal of experience in designing web sites but using inline styling and and embedded styling should be avoided when using CSS.  It tends to make sites difficult to maintain and has not been recommended for quite some time by the W3C.  
The subjects are covered well but are not complete.  Slowing down and using different types of demonstrations would really help the viewers better understand what you are trying to cover.
results.content_html:
I understand the accent and the difficulty in teaching in a second language, but Shahzaib really should slow down with the speech patterns. He does a good job with the language but goes very fast when talking. Also get away from using the term perfect so often, very few things in life are perfect.
I would also recommend that you follow "Best Practices" when writing code. It is obvious you have a good deal of experience in designing web sites but using inline styling and and embedded styling should be avoided when using CSS. It tends to make sites difficult to maintain and has not been recommended for quite some time by the W3C.
The subjects are covered well but are not complete. Slowing down and using different types of demonstrations would really help the viewers better understand what you are trying to cover.

results.content:
The course is not well organized at all.  It seems like only a small amount of effort was put into creating the course. 

Here are the problems:

General: 

1.  You cannot download the source code

2.  They don't provide you with the resources (images etc, they used to create the projects -- so how are we supposed to recreate them?) If you browse the Q&A, you'll see that the instructor promised 8 MONTHS AGO that he will provide the resources ASAP (quite a few people are asking for them), and well, he still didn't. 

3. For the four projects, the instructor just immediately starts coding.  He doesn't actually introduce the project and what he'll be doing. In fact, it is impossible to know the end result of what you're making till you follow through all the lectures pertaining to the section, which is quite ridiculous. So you're writing code blindly - you're just typing what he's typing on the screen.

4. In Section 1, he demonstrates what bootstrap can do. It is actually not that bad, but the problem is there are no exercises. So you watch over 30 videos of how to do this and that. Obviously, if you don't practice it, you'll never learn. I was looking forward to the quiz, to try to see what I retained. The quiz was a joke. It was 2 very, very, very basic questions that don't actually test your knowledge. I guess they were just there to make selling the course easier (oh look we have a quiz!)

All in all, I'm demanding a refund.
results.content_html:

Obviously, if you don't practice it, you'll never learn. I was looking forward to the quiz, to try to see what I retained. The quiz was a joke. It was 2 very, very, very basic questions that don't actually test your knowledge. I guess they were just there to make selling the course easier (oh look we have a quiz!)

All in all, I'm demanding a refund.

results.content:
You should definitely have some familiarity with basic HTML and CSS before taking this course because the instructor does teach in a way that assumes you have some knowledge. That being said, I really find this course very enjoyable and I feel like I'm finally learning Bootstrap the right way. 
The head instructor gives a friendly heads-up on the instructor's accent, but I actually think the on-video instructor is one cool dude! I had worked with Bootstrap before, but this course is really helping me sharpen my skills and develop a true understanding of how to use Bootstrap. 
I'm looking forward to completing it and using my new skills for future projects. Great course, highly recommended! Bootstrap is awesome.
results.content_html:
You should definitely have some familiarity with basic HTML and CSS before taking this course because the instructor does teach in a way that assumes you have some knowledge. That being said, I really find this course very enjoyable and I feel like I'm finally learning Bootstrap the right way.
The head instructor gives a friendly heads-up on the instructor's accent, but I actually think the on-video instructor is one cool dude! I had worked with Bootstrap before, but this course is really helping me sharpen my skills and develop a true understanding of how to use Bootstrap.
I'm looking forward to completing it and using my new skills for future projects. Great course, highly recommended! Bootstrap is awesome.

results.content:
Die ersten 39 Videos erklären die CSS-Klassen. Die Vorstellung ist unheimlich langweilig und schlecht vorbereitet. Man kann zuschauen, wie der Autor CSS Code eingibt, sich dabei sehr oft verschreibt. Bootstrap hat bereits eine SEHR gute Referenz im Netz und man erhält alle Informationen schnell und übersichtlich. Die vielen Videos anschauen zu müssen ist daher eher anstrengend als hilfreich.
Meine Hoffnung sind die Abschnitte 2+, da hier Designs vorgestellt werden. Ich habe bisher nur 1 Video geschaut und muss sagen, dass ich sehr enttäuscht bin. Alles schein unvorbereitet zu sein, der Autor sagt nicht, was er eigentlich erreichen will, so dass man in Gedanken in der Lage ist den Videos zu folgen. Es werden viele Fehler gemacht. Es erschaut als wäre nach dem "Try & Error" Prinzip gearbeitet worden. 

Zu Schluss ist noch zu sagen, dass die Sprache des Autors extrem anstrengend ist. Die Videos haben oft sehr unterschiedliche Lautstärken, die Betonung ist ermüdet und eintönig. Der Dialekt des Autors ist anstrengend und es macht einem schwer mehr als 10 Min ab Stück den Videos aufmerksam zu folgen.

Zusammenfassend: Ich bin sehr enttäuscht von dem Kurz. Auch wenn ich bisher nicht alle Videos geschaut habe, so ist dies meine Meinung nach ca. 50% der Videos. Ich werde meine Meinung gern überarbeiten, wenn sich in den letzte Videos zeigt, dass die Qualität doch noch zunimmt.
results.content_html:
Die ersten 39 Videos erklären die CSS-Klassen. Die Vorstellung ist unheimlich langweilig und schlecht vorbereitet. Man kann zuschauen, wie der Autor CSS Code eingibt, sich dabei sehr oft verschreibt. Bootstrap hat bereits eine SEHR gute Referenz im Netz und man erhält alle Informationen schnell und übersichtlich. Die vielen Videos anschauen zu müssen ist daher eher anstrengend als hilfreich.
Meine Hoffnung sind die Abschnitte 2+, da hier Designs vorgestellt werden. Ich habe bisher nur 1 Video geschaut und muss sagen, dass ich sehr enttäuscht bin. Alles schein unvorbereitet zu sein, der Autor sagt nicht, was er eigentlich erreichen will, so dass man in Gedanken in der Lage ist den Videos zu folgen. Es werden viele Fehler gemacht. Es erschaut als wäre nach dem "Try & Error" Prinzip gearbeitet worden.

Zu Schluss ist noch zu sagen, dass die Sprache des Autors extrem anstrengend ist. Die Videos haben oft sehr unterschiedliche Lautstärken, die Betonung ist ermüdet und eintönig. Der Dialekt des Autors ist anstrengend und es macht einem schwer mehr als 10 Min ab Stück den Videos aufmerksam zu folgen.

Zusammenfassend: Ich bin sehr enttäuscht von dem Kurz. Auch wenn ich bisher nicht alle Videos geschaut habe, so ist dies meine Meinung nach ca. 50% der Videos. Ich werde meine Meinung gern überarbeiten, wenn sich in den letzte Videos zeigt, dass die Qualität doch noch zunimmt.

results.content: The video content seems a little disorganized, there's some jumping around that's hard to keep up with, hence clarity of the content can be improved. Some explanation for CDN and Download would definitely be nice for a total beginner - why it's a good idea to Download rather than use CDN in our files. The voice overs could also be slowed down.

results.content: Much of the class consists of the instructor typing rapidly, making mistakes, typing rapidly, correcting mistakes, so the actual usable content in a lesson is diminished. Plus his pronunciation for a US/UK audience is sometimes difficult ( pronouncing row as "raw" for example ).
